Article.Abstract: Adenoviruses often cause lethal infections in immunocompromised individuals. Adoptive transfer of immune T cells offers a therapeutic option, but this strategy has been hindered by the paucity of information on molecular targets of cellular immunity and by the immunologic heterogeneity of the 51 human adenoviruses, which are grouped from A to F on the basis of genome size, composition, homology, and organization. Clonal analysis of the adenovirus-specific cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) responses of seropositive individuals identified 5 novel CD8(+) T-cell epitopes, all located in conserved regions of the capsid protein hexon. Reactive T cells were cross-reactive between 2 to 4 groups, while no T cells specific for a single subgroup were detected. Thus, by exploiting these peptide targets, it is possible to prepare a T-cell population capable of reacting with most adenoviruses that cause disease in immunocompromised patients.
Article.ArticleTitle: Conserved CTL epitopes on the adenovirus hexon protein expand subgroup cross-reactive and subgroup-specific CD8+ T cells.
Article.Affiliations: Center for Cell and Gene Therapy, Department of Pediatrics, 6621 Fannin St, MC 3-3320, Houston, TX, USA.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Exposure with existing immune reactivity without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were from adenovirus-seropositive human volunteers. CTL clones were generated by in vitro restimulation of PBMCs followed by single cell cloning.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Positive staining was observed with PBMCs and the epitope-specific CTL clone.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Exposure with existing immune reactivity without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were from adenovirus-seropositive human volunteers. CTL clones were generated by in vitro restimulation of PBMCs followed by single cell cloning.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific CTL clone lysed target cells transduced with Ad7, Ad11 of subgroup B, Ad2, Ad5, Ad6 of subgroup B, Ad8 of subgroup D, and Ad4 of subgroup E. The CTL clone did not lyse cells transduced with Ad5 of subgroup C.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Exposure with existing immune reactivity without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were from adenovirus-seropositive human volunteers. CTL clones were generated by in vitro restimulation of PBMCs followed by single cell cloning.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific CTL clone produced IFN-gamma in response to the epitope.
